questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of severe ear pain and yellow discharge from her left ear for the past 2 days. It is also mildly pruritic. The pain started during her last day of summer camp, where she spent a lot of time outdoors hiking, horseback riding, and swimming. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mm Hg. Examination shows tragal tenderness and a red and edematous external auditory canal. A diagnostic tuning fork is placed in the middle of the patient's forehead. The patient reports hearing the sound louder in the left ear. The tuning fork is then placed on the mastoid process of the left ear. Once she can no longer hear the sound, the tuning fork is placed in front of the auricle, and she reports no longer hearing the sound. On the right side, once the sound from the mastoid process subsides and the tuning fork is placed in front of the right ear, she reports hearing the sound again. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Infections of the external ear with Aspergillus or Candida are the most common causes of fungal otitis externa. Fungal infection of the external ear accounts for < 10% of otitis externa cases and is usually associated with concurrent antibiotic use. While patients may present with tragal discomfort and ear discharge, they usually have less severe ear edema, erythema, and pain than with the more common causes of otitis externa. In addition, intense ear itching is usually the primary symptom of fungal otitis externa.

B) INCORRECT:

Herpes zoster oticus is caused by infection of the external ear with the varicella zoster virus. Like otitis externa, it is associated with tragal tenderness. However, herpes zoster oticus typically manifests with blisters on the external ear, face, and mouth. Patients can present with vertigo, facial paralysis, tinnitus, and dysgeusia (loss of taste). Moreover, herpes zoster oticus is associated with sensorineural hearing loss rather than conductive hearing loss.

C) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus pneumoniae rarely infects the external ear, but it is a common cause of otitis media. While otitis media may also manifest with discharge from the ear and conductive hearing loss, tragal tenderness and ear canal edema are usually absent. Furthermore, otitis media tends to occur in winter months and is often associated with a history of cold and congestion.

D) INCORRECT:

Abnormal squamous epithelial growth leads to cholesteatoma, which is often asymptomatic. Although cholesteatoma may manifest with discharge from the ear and conductive hearing loss, this condition typically affects the middle ear and is not associated with tragal tenderness or external ear edema.

E) CORRECT:

Most cases of otitis externa are caused by bacterial infection; Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most common pathogen (∼ 40% of cases). Risk factors include increased moisture in the external auditory canal (e.g., from swimming) and/or injury to the overlying skin of the external auditory canal. Other causes of bacterial otitis externa include infection with Staphylococcus aureus, Escherichia coli, and Proteus mirabilis.
Image Description:

There is swelling and mild erythema of the external auditory canal and auricle. Purulent discharge from the external auditory canal is visible. The auditory canal appears to be obstructed.

These findings are consistent with otitis externa.

F) INCORRECT:

Otosclerosis involves a pleomorphic replacement of normal bone and leads to progressive conductive hearing loss in adults. However, this condition is not associated with tragal tenderness, external ear edema, or discharge from the ear.
questions.hint: A Weber test that lateralizes to the affected ear (the left ear in this patient) in combination with a negative Rinne test in the same ear suggests conductive hearing loss. Ear pain, otorrhea, pruritus, and an edematous, reddened external auditory canal indicate that the cause of conductive hearing loss is otitis externa.

questions.text: Following the patient's third episode of otitis externa this summer, her parents ask whether there is anything they can do to prevent the further recurrence of this condition. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation by the physician?

choices.text: Application of alcohol-based ear drops after swimming activities
Remove cerumen from the ear canal regularly
Oral use of ciprofloxacin prior to swimming activities
Topical use of hydrocortisone cream after swimming activities
Application of antibiotic ear drops after swimming activities
Limit swimming activities to a maximum of 1x/week

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Application of acetic acid and/or alcohol-based ear drops helps to dry the ear and reacidify the ear canal. Patients who engage in frequent water activities are at increased risk for recurrent episodes of otitis externa; protecting the ears by keeping the auricle and external auditory canal clean and dry is the most effective prevention strategy. Other measures to prevent recurrence include carefully blow-drying the ear, wearing a bathing cap during water activities, treatment of underlying dermatological disorders, and avoiding manipulation of the ear canal.

B) INCORRECT:

The removal of cerumen from the ear canal may be indicated to acutely evaluate and treat otitis externa. However, cerumen should only be removed by a healthcare provider to prevent damaging the ear and making it more vulnerable to infection. Patients should be counseled not to remove cerumen because it helps protect the ear canal from infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral ciprofloxacin is used to treat severe otitis externa, otitis externa in patients at risk of developing complications (e.g., immunosuppressed patients, patients with diabetes mellitus), and in patients in whom topical treatment is not possible. This patient is not presenting with any symptoms concerning for severe otitis externa and does not have any conditions that would necessitate oral treatment. Moreover, oral antibiotics are not used to prevent recurrent otitis externa.

D) INCORRECT:

Hydrocortisone can be used after swimming to prevent the recurrence of otitis externa when combined with alcohol solutions, and as an acute treatment for edema and inflammation. However, in both instances, drops are used rather than creams, which increase moisture retention. The key to the prevention of recurrent episodes of otitis externa is keeping the ear canal clean and dry, so cream formulations are not recommended.

E) INCORRECT:

Antibiotic ear drops are used to treat acute otitis externa; however, they are not helpful in preventing recurrent episodes. The antibiotics typically used in acute treatment are ofloxacin, ciprofloxacin, or neomycin.

F) INCORRECT:

Limiting swimming activities can be considered for patients with acute otitis externa, but measures that limit the patient's social and physical activities are not the first line for prevention of recurrence of this condition. Ear hygiene measures are effective in reducing the risk of recurrence, so other preventative strategies should be tried first.
questions.hint: Prevention of recurrent otitis externa in children emphasizes aural hygiene, which includes keeping the auricle and external auditory canal clean and dry.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 4-day history of severe, left-sided ear pain and purulent discharge from his left ear. One week ago, he returned with his family from their annual summer vacation at a lakeside cabin, where he spent most of the time outdoors hiking and swimming. Examination shows tragal tenderness and a markedly edematous and erythematous external auditory canal. Audiometry shows conductive hearing loss of the left ear. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Abnormal epithelial growth on tympanic membrane

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A cholesteatoma is a growth of keratinizing squamous epithelium from the tympanic membrane or auditory canal into the middle ear mucosa. It is often asymptomatic, but it can manifest with discharge from the ear, dizziness, and conductive hearing loss. However, it affects the middle ear and is therefore not associated with tragal tenderness or edema of the external auditory canal.

B) INCORRECT:

Aspergillus and Candida species are the most common causal pathogens of fungal otitis externa, which can manifest with tragal pain, ear discharge, edema, and erythema. However, in fungal otitis externa, the pain is usually not severe and the edema is usually mild. Pruritus is normally the most troubling symptom. Furthermore, fungal otitis externa accounts for < 10% of all otitis externa cases and is usually associated with concurrent antibiotic use.

C) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus pneumoniae, a common cause of otitis media, rarely infects the external ear. While otitis media can manifest with ear pain and discharge as well as conductive hearing loss, tragal tenderness and edema of the external auditory canal are usually absent. Furthermore, otitis media tends to occur in winter months and is often associated with a history of cold and congestion.

D) INCORRECT:

Infection of the external ear with the varicella zoster virus causes herpes zoster oticus, which can manifest with tragal tenderness. However, herpes zoster oticus is usually associated with facial paralysis and blisters in or on the ear as well as vertigo, tinnitus, and dysgeusia. Moreover, herpes zoster oticus usually results in sensorineural hearing loss rather than conductive hearing loss.

E) INCORRECT:

Otosclerosis involves pleomorphic replacement of the normal bone. It causes slowly progressive conductive hearing loss in adults but is not associated with ear pain, discharge, tragal tenderness, or edema of the external auditory canal.

F) CORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most common causal pathogen of otitis externa (commonly following swimming activities). Other common causal pathogens of otitis externa include Staphylococcus epidermidis and Staphylococcus aureus.
questions.hint: The patient has ear pain and purulent discharge after returning from a vacation that involved outdoor swimming. Examination shows an inflamed external auditory canal and conductive hearing loss. These features are consistent with otitis externa.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician because of a painful left ear with discharge for the past 5 days. The ear pain is constant and slightly improves with over-the-counter ibuprofen. He has no personal history of serious illnesses. He works as a sound technician for a rock band and uses earplugs almost the entire day. He smokes two packs of cigarettes and drinks three to four beers daily. His immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 128/80 mm Hg. Examination of the left ear discloses a swollen pinna and a malodorous discharge from the external auditory meatus; the tragus is tender to touch. Otoscopic examination of the left ear shows a swollen ear canal. The tympanic membrane appears normal. Fingerstick blood glucose concentration is 90 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Ear swabs, blood cultures, CT scan of the temporal bone, and systemic therapy with intravenous ciprofloxacin
Ear swabs and topical therapy with clotrimazole and acetic acid
Topical therapy with betamethasone and acetic acid, and systemic therapy with oral ciprofloxacin
Topical therapy with ciprofloxacin and hydrocortisone

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An extensive diagnostic workup and intravenous ciprofloxacin are required in patients suspected to have malignant otitis externa (MOE). Severe ear pain and otorrhea are typical manifestations of this condition. However, this patient has no risk factors for MOE (e.g., immunosuppression, diabetes mellitus), and otoscopic examination shows no evidence of granulation tissue, which would be expected in this condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Clotrimazole ear drops are recommended for the treatment of fungal otitis externa, which manifests with ear pain and otorrhea. However, this condition is characterized by excessive ear itching. Antifungal therapy for AOE is indicated if the initial therapy is insufficient or if features suggestive of fungal infection (e.g., fungal filaments and spores) are seen on otoscopy. Moreover, ear swabs are only performed if the patient does not respond to initial therapy or in cases of severe AOE (i.e., completely occluded EAC, fever), whereas this patient has uncomplicated AOE.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral amoxicillin-clavulanate is the first-line therapy for acute otitis media (AOM) because of its efficacy against Streptococcus pneumonia and Haemophilus influenzae, the most common causal pathogens of AOM. AOM can manifest with ear pain and otorrhea. However, AOM is also characterized by a red bulging tympanic membrane on otoscopy. Amoxicillin-clavulanate is not effective against Pseudomonas aeruginosa, the most common cause of acute otitis externa.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical therapy with a steroid and an antiseptic is recommended as part of the treatment for uncomplicated AOE, which this patient has. However, systemic therapy with oral ciprofloxacin is only indicated in patients with AOE and immunosuppression, diabetes mellitus, or severe otitis externa with cellulitis of the face and neck, or if topical administration is not possible or ineffective. Topical antibiotic treatment is preferred in this patient.

E) CORRECT:

AOE is treated with a topical preparation that contains a steroid (e.g., hydrocortisone, betamethasone) and an antimicrobial that is effective against the most common causative bacteria of AOE (e.g., aminoglycoside, fluoroquinolone). A commonly used and effective combination is ciprofloxacin and hydrocortisone. Alternatively, a combination of neomycin, polymyxin B, and hydrocortisone may be used. Further treatment includes aural toilet to remove debris and NSAIDs for pain relief. The tympanic membrane (TM) must be assessed prior to initiating therapy; if the TM is not intact or cannot be visualized, topical aminoglycosides and aural toilet are contraindicated because of an increased risk of damage to the middle ear. Ear swabs and oral antibiotic therapy should be considered if the patient does not respond to initial therapy, has severe AOE (i.e., completely occluded external auditory canal, fever, cervical lymphadenitis), or has risk factors for malignant otitis externa (e.g., immunosuppression, diabetes mellitus).

In mild cases of AOE (i.e., only mild discomfort or pruritus with minimal edema of the auditory canal), a topical antiseptic preparation (e.g., acetic acid) without an antibiotic may be considered. Patients suspected to have malignant otitis externa require a more extensive diagnostic workup (e.g., blood cultures, CT scan) and intravenous antibiotic therapy in addition to topical therapy.
questions.hint: Severe ear pain, otorrhea, ear canal edema, and a tragus tender to touch are suggestive of acute otitis externa (AOE), which is most commonly caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Staphylococcus aureus. Using earplugs can cause injury to the skin and increase moisture in the external auditory canal, which increases the risk of AOE.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man reports 2 days of worsening pain in his right ear. He has occasional drainage from that ear and reports that the pain prevents him from sleeping with the right side of his head on the pillow. He reports no fevers, dizziness, or nasal congestion. He is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. He works in construction.
On physical examination, he reports tenderness with pressure on the tragus and with manipulation of the pinna. There is edema and yellow debris in the ear canal. The tympanic membrane is visible and intact, with some yellow exudate on it. The middle ear is aerated. The patient’s facial motion is intact, and there is no nystagmus.
Which one of the following initial treatments is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Otic drop containing an antibiotic and a glucocorticoid

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral antibiotics are not routinely needed for otherwise healthy patients with AOE. Exceptions to this are cases in which the tympanic membrane is not visible due to drainage or swelling and the swelling and tenderness have spread outside the ear canal. Oral antibiotics are almost always used in patients who have diabetes or are immunocompromised. In addition, although amoxicillin is the most common first-line medication for acute otitis media, it would not cover Pseudomonas. Resolution of symptoms usually starts after 48 hours of treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Clotrimazole can be used for fungal infections, but fungi rarely cause AOE in healthy individuals.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral methylprednisolone is appropriate for acute hearing loss but not for AOE.

D) INCORRECT:

Carbamide peroxide is used to help dissolve ear wax.

E) CORRECT:

Acute otitis externa (AOE) — a cellulitis of the ear canal, skin, and subdermis — is almost always caused by bacteria. Pseudomonas and Staphylococcus are the most frequent pathogens involved in AOE. Patients who swim or use ear plugs or cotton swabs are at higher risk for AOE. Symptoms begin with acute-onset, severe unilateral ear pain and may include yellow or bloody otorrhea.

Patients with AOE typically have a swollen and moist ear canal. Manipulation of the tragus and pinna produces pain that appears to be out of proportion with the examination findings. The eardrum may be erythematous but with no middle-ear effusion. Using pneumatic otoscopy to differentiate AOE from acute otitis media is helpful but may be difficult because pressure from the otoscope speculum causes pain.

Antibacterial otic drops, the most appropriate initial treatment for AOE, should contain a glucocorticoid to mitigate inflammation, relieve pain, and aid in drug delivery. Dry-ear precautions should also be observed.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial treatment for acute otitis externa is antimicrobial otic drops that cover Pseudomonas and Staphylococcus and that contain a glucocorticoid. Adding the topical glucocorticoid helps reduce swelling and pain faster.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old male lifeguard with no significant medical history presents for evaluation of severe pain, itching, and yellow drainage in his left ear. The symptoms started about 24 hours ago in the absence of any trauma.
The patient has a body temperature of 36.9°C, a respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and a heart rate of 76 beats per minute. External ear examination reveals tenderness on palpation and tugging of the left pinna, but no erythema or edema. Otoscopy reveals a red, swollen ear canal containing yellow debris. The debris is gently removed. Visualization of the tympanic membrane is partially obscured by ear-canal edema. There are no visible air-fluid levels along the tympanic membrane, and insufflation reveals that the tympanic membrane is mobile. There is no periauricular edema or cervical lymphadenopathy. The rest of the physical examination is normal.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Dexamethasone 0.1% suspension to the affected ear twice daily
Clotrimazole 1% solution to the affected ear twice daily
Ciprofloxacin 500 mg twice daily by mouth
Ciprofloxacin 0.2%-hydrocortisone 1% otic solution to the affected ear twice daily
Prednisone 60 mg once daily by mouth

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Because data are limited on the use of glucocorticoids (e.g., prednisone, dexamethasone) as monotherapy for otitis externa, these medications are not typically used as first-line treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical antifungals (e.g., clotrimazole) are not appropriate for treating acute otitis externa unless the cause is known to be fungal or standard therapy fails. Fungal infection can occur in up to 10% of patients with otitis externa, but it usually manifests with either white debris (in the case of Candida) or grey chalky debris (with Aspergillus) and is not usually severely painful.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral antibiotics are not recommended as monotherapy for otitis externa — and are recommended in conjunction with topical therapy only for patients who have deeper tissue infection (beyond the external auditory canal) or are immunocompromised (such as those who have undergone organ transplantation, those receiving chemotherapy or radiation therapy, and those with HIV disease or uncontrolled diabetes).

D) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation and history are consistent with uncomplicated acute otitis externa (AOE), a cellulitis of the ear canal, skin, and subdermis. Typical symptoms of acute otitis externa include ear pain, itching, discharge, and tenderness to the touch. Hearing loss is typically mild and only occurs later in the infection, when ear-canal swelling blocks the canal. This presentation is distinct from that of acute otitis media, where ear pain is initially severe but the ear is not tender to the touch, and hearing diminishes almost immediately as the ear drum swells and the middle ear fills with fluid.

Patients with AOE typically have a swollen and moist ear canal. The ear drum may be difficult to see but is usually normal, and the middle ear is aerated. Examination with an otoscope is usually painful for these patients. In contrast, in patients with acute otitis media, the ear canal is normal-sized and nontender, the ear drum is red and bulging, and the middle ear will have fluid or pus. If the ear drum ruptures, a perforation may be visible, but it may also be very difficult to see through the drainage. The differential for acute ear pain with debris in the canal includes both ruptured otitis media and otitis externa, so the presence of edema in the canal, the demonstration of pain with tugging the ear lobe, and (whenever possible) the gentle removal of debris are all helpful to establish the diagnosis. In some patients, the debris will need to be cleared by an otolaryngologist using binocular microscopic guidance.

In severe cases of acute otitis externa, the infection may spread to the auricle and surrounding structures with erythema, edema, tenderness, and often upper cervical adenopathy. Such spread is rarely seen in acute otitis media.

The recommended treatment for uncomplicated acute otitis externa is either a topical antiseptic, such as acetic acid, or a topical antibiotic-glucocorticoid combination, such as ciprofloxacin-hydrocortisone. The antibiotic component of the combination should have activity against the two bacteria most frequently associated with otitis externa: Staphylococcus aureus and Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

Topical treatment for uncomplicated otitis externa is preferred over oral treatment because it delivers a high concentration of medication to the affected tissue with minimal systemic adverse effects. A 2010 meta-analysis revealed no significant differences among topical antibiotic agents with respect to clinical or microbiologic cure rates; there was a suggestion that adding a high-potency glucocorticoid to the topical antibiotic could reduce swelling, but the magnitude of a possible effect could not be determined with the data available.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for uncomplicated acute otitis externa in an otherwise healthy adult is a topical antibiotic-glucocorticoid combination or a topical antiseptic.

E) INCORRECT:

Because data are limited on the use of glucocorticoids (e.g., prednisone, dexamethasone) as monotherapy for otitis externa, these medications are not typically used as first-line treatment.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old boy presents for evaluation of severe pain, itching, and yellow drainage in his left ear. He has been working as a summer camp counselor and has no significant medical history. His current symptoms started about 24 hours ago in the absence of any trauma.
He has a body temperature of 36.9°C, a respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and a heart rate of 76 beats per minute. External ear examination reveals tenderness on palpation and tugging of the left pinna, but no erythema or edema. Otoscopy reveals a red, swollen ear canal containing yellow debris. The debris is gently removed. Visualization of the tympanic membrane is partially obscured by ear-canal edema. There are no visible air-fluid levels along the tympanic membrane, and insufflation reveals that the tympanic membrane is mobile. There is no periauricular edema or cervical lymphadenopathy. The rest of the physical examination is normal.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Clotrimazole 1% solution to the affected ear twice daily
Alcohol-acetic acid drops in the affected ear twice daily
Ciprofloxacin 0.2%-hydrocortisone 1% otic solution to the affected ear twice daily
Dexamethasone 0.1% suspension to the affected ear twice daily
Mupirocin topically to the affected ear canal twice daily

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical antifungals (e.g., clotrimazole) are not appropriate for treating acute otitis externa unless the cause is known to be fungal or standard therapy fails. Fungal infection can occur in up to 10% of patients with otitis externa, but it usually manifests with either white debris (in the case of Candida) or grey chalky debris (with Aspergillus) and is not usually severely painful.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical antiseptic alone (alcohol-acetic acid) will not be sufficient for the bacterial component in this patient’s ear (as evidenced by yellow discharge, edema, and erythema).

C) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation and history are consistent with uncomplicated acute otitis externa (AOE), a cellulitis of the ear canal, skin, and subdermis. Typical symptoms of acute otitis externa include ear pain, itching, discharge, and tenderness to the touch. Hearing loss is typically mild and only occurs later in the infection, when ear-canal swelling blocks the canal. This presentation is distinct from that of acute otitis media, where ear pain is initially severe but the ear is not tender to the touch, and hearing diminishes almost immediately as the ear drum swells and the middle ear fills with fluid.

Patients with AOE typically have a swollen and moist ear canal. The ear drum may be difficult to see but is usually normal, and the middle ear is aerated. Examination with an otoscope is usually painful for these patients. In contrast, in patients with acute otitis media, the ear canal is normal-sized and nontender, the ear drum is red and bulging, and the middle ear will have fluid or pus. If the ear drum ruptures, a perforation may be visible, but it may also be very difficult to see through the drainage. The differential for acute ear pain with debris in the canal includes both ruptured otitis media and otitis externa, so the presence of edema in the canal, the demonstration of pain with tugging the ear lobe, and (whenever possible) the gentle removal of debris are all helpful to establish the diagnosis. In some patients, the debris will need to be cleared by an otolaryngologist using binocular microscopic guidance.

In severe cases of acute otitis externa, the infection may spread to the auricle and surrounding structures with erythema, edema, tenderness, and often upper cervical adenopathy. Such spread is rarely seen in acute otitis media.

The antibiotic component of the combination should have activity against the two bacteria most frequently associated with otitis externa: Staphylococcus aureus and Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

Topical treatment for uncomplicated otitis externa is preferred over oral treatment because it delivers a high concentration of medication to the affected tissue with minimal systemic adverse effects. A 2010 meta-analysis revealed no significant differences among topical antibiotic agents with respect to clinical or microbiologic cure rates; there was a suggestion that adding a high-potency glucocorticoid to the topical antibiotic could reduce swelling, but the magnitude of a possible effect could not be determined with the data available.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for uncomplicated acute otitis externa in an otherwise healthy adolescent is a topical antibiotic-glucocorticoid combination or a topical antiseptic.

D) INCORRECT:

The recommended treatment for uncomplicated acute otitis externa is either a topical antiseptic, such as acetic acid, or a topical antibiotic-glucocorticoid combination, such as ciprofloxacin-hydrocortisone. There is no mention of dexamethasone alone being an appropriate therapy for acute otitis externa.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical antibiotic cream or ointment such as mupirocin is helpful in cases of skin infection caused by methicillin-resistant S. aureus, but this diagnosis does not fit with the clinical picture of acute otitis externa in this patient.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old boy presents with 2 days of worsening pain in his right ear. He has occasional drainage from that ear and reports that the pain prevents him from sleeping with the right side of his head on the pillow. He reports no fevers, dizziness, or nasal congestion. He is otherwise healthy and takes no medications.
On physical examination, he reports tenderness with pressure on the tragus and with manipulation of the pinna. There is edema and yellow debris in the ear canal. The tympanic membrane is visible and intact, with some yellow exudate on it. The middle ear is aerated. The patient’s facial motion is intact, and there is no nystagmus.
Which one of the following initial treatments is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Otic drop containing an antibiotic and a glucocorticoid

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Acute otitis externa (AOE) — a cellulitis of the ear canal, skin, and subdermis — is almost always caused by bacteria. Pseudomonas and Staphylococcus are the most frequent pathogens involved in AOE. Patients who swim or use ear plugs or cotton swabs are at higher risk for AOE. Symptoms begin with acute-onset, severe unilateral ear pain and may include yellow or bloody otorrhea.

The eardrum may be erythematous but with no middle-ear effusion. Using pneumatic otoscopy to differentiate AOE from acute otitis media is helpful but may be difficult because pressure from the otoscope speculum causes pain.

Antibacterial otic drops, the most appropriate initial treatment for AOE, should contain a glucocorticoid to mitigate inflammation, relieve pain, and aid in drug delivery. Dry-ear precautions should also be observed.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial treatment for acute otitis externa is antimicrobial otic drops that cover Pseudomonas and Staphylococcus and that contain a glucocorticoid. Adding the topical glucocorticoid helps reduce swelling and pain faster.

B) INCORRECT:

Clotrimazole can be used for fungal infections, but fungi rarely cause AOE in healthy individuals.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral antibiotics are not routinely needed for otherwise healthy patients with AOE. Exceptions to this are cases in which the tympanic membrane is not visible due to drainage or swelling and the swelling and tenderness have spread outside the ear canal. Oral antibiotics are almost always used in patients who have diabetes or are immunocompromised. In addition, although amoxicillin is the most common first-line medication for acute otitis media, it would not cover Pseudomonas.

D) INCORRECT:

Carbamide peroxide is used to help dissolve ear wax.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical treatment is sufficient, and oral methylprednisolone would not be appropriate for AOE.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 4-day history of severe, left-sided ear pain and purulent discharge from his left ear. He had recently been swimming in a lake. Examination shows tragal tenderness and a markedly edematous and erythematous external auditory canal. Audiometry shows conductive hearing loss in the left ear. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Abnormal epithelial growth on tympanic membrane

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A cholesteatoma is a growth of keratinizing squamous epithelium from the tympanic membrane or auditory canal into the middle ear mucosa. It is often asymptomatic, but it can manifest with discharge from the ear, dizziness, and conductive hearing loss. However, it affects the middle ear and is therefore not associated with tragal tenderness or edema of the external auditory canal.

B) INCORRECT:

Aspergillus and Candida species are the most common causal pathogens of fungal otitis externa, which can manifest with tragal pain, ear discharge, edema, and erythema. However, in fungal otitis externa, the pain is usually not severe and the edema is usually mild. Pruritus is normally the most troubling symptom. Furthermore, fungal otitis externa accounts for < 10% of all otitis externa cases and is usually associated with concurrent antibiotic use.

C) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus pneumoniae, a common cause of otitis media, rarely infects the external ear. While otitis media can manifest with ear pain and discharge as well as conductive hearing loss, tragal tenderness and edema of the external auditory canal are usually absent. Furthermore, otitis media tends to occur in winter months and is often associated with a history of cold and congestion.

D) INCORRECT:

Infection of the external ear with the varicella zoster virus causes herpes zoster oticus, which can manifest with tragal tenderness. However, herpes zoster oticus is usually associated with facial paralysis and blisters in or on the ear as well as vertigo, tinnitus, and dysgeusia. Moreover, herpes zoster oticus usually results in sensorineural hearing loss rather than conductive hearing loss.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most common causal pathogen of otitis externa (commonly following swimming activities). Other common causal pathogens of otitis externa include Staphylococcus epidermidis and Staphylococcus aureus.

Treatment typically involves analgesia, keeping the external acoustic meatus dry, and administering antiseptic, antibiotic, or glucocorticoid ear drops.
questions.hint: The patient has ear pain and purulent discharge after outdoor swimming. Examination shows an inflamed external auditory canal and conductive hearing loss. These features are consistent with otitis externa.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man comes to the office because of a painful left ear with discharge for the past 5 days. He works as a sound technician and uses earplugs almost the entire day. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the left ear discloses a swollen pinna and a malodorous discharge from the external auditory meatus; the tragus is tender to touch. Otoscopic examination of the left ear shows a swollen ear canal. The tympanic membrane appears normal. Fingerstick blood glucose concentration is normal. Which of the following initial treatments is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Otic drop containing an antibiotic and a glucocorticoid

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous ciprofloxacin is used in patients suspected to have malignant otitis externa (MOE). Severe ear pain and otorrhea are typical manifestations of this condition. However, this patient has no risk factors for MOE (e.g., immunosuppression, diabetes mellitus), and otoscopic examination shows no evidence of granulation tissue, which would be expected in this condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Clotrimazole ear drops are recommended for the treatment of fungal otitis externa, which manifests with ear pain and otorrhea. However, this condition is characterized by excessive ear itching. Antifungal therapy for AOE is indicated if the initial therapy is insufficient or if features suggestive of fungal infection (e.g., fungal filaments and spores) are seen on otoscopy.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral amoxicillin-clavulanate is the first-line therapy for acute otitis media (AOM) because of its efficacy against Streptococcus pneumonia and Haemophilus influenzae, the most common causal pathogens of AOM. AOM can manifest with ear pain and otorrhea. However, AOM is also characterized by a red bulging tympanic membrane on otoscopy. Amoxicillin-clavulanate is not effective against Pseudomonas aeruginosa, the most common cause of acute otitis externa.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral methylprednisolone is appropriate for acute hearing loss but not for acute otitis externa.

E) CORRECT:

Uncomplicated AOE is treated with a topical preparation that contains an antibiotic that is effective against the most common causative bacteria of AOE (e.g., aminoglycoside, fluoroquinolone), a glucocorticoid (e.g., hydrocortisone, betamethasone), and an antiseptic (e.g., alcohol, acetic acid). Further treatment includes aural toilet to remove debris and NSAIDs for pain relief. The tympanic membrane (TM) must be assessed prior to initiating therapy; if the TM is not intact or cannot be visualized, topical aminoglycosides and aural toilette are contraindicated because of an increased risk of damage to the middle ear. Ear swabs and oral antibiotic therapy should be considered if the patient does not respond to initial therapy, has severe AOE (i.e., completely occluded external auditory canal, fever, cervical lymphadenitis), or has risk factors for malignant otitis externa (e.g., immunosuppression, diabetes mellitus).

In mild cases of AOE (i.e., only mild discomfort or pruritus with minimal edema of the auditory canal), a topical preparation without an antibiotic may be considered. Patients suspected to have malignant otitis externa require a more extensive diagnostic workup (e.g., blood cultures, CT scan) and intravenous antibiotic therapy in addition to topical therapy.
questions.hint: Severe ear pain, otorrhea, ear canal edema, and a tragus tender to touch are suggestive of acute otitis externa (AOE), which is most commonly caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Staphylococcus aureus. Using earplugs can cause injury to the skin and increase moisture in the external auditory canal, which increases the risk of AOE.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with a 4-day history of severe left-sided ear pain and purulent discharge from his left ear. He recently went swimming in a lake. On examination, there is tenderness over the tragus and the external auditory canal is markedly edematous and erythematous. Audiometry reveals conductive hearing loss in the left ear. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?

choices.text: Abnormal epithelial growth on tympanic membrane.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A cholesteatoma is a growth of keratinizing squamous epithelium from the tympanic membrane or auditory canal into the middle ear mucosa. It is often asymptomatic, but it can manifest with discharge from the ear, dizziness, and conductive hearing loss. However, it affects the middle ear and is therefore not associated with tragal tenderness or edema of the external auditory canal.

B) INCORRECT:

Infection of the external ear with the varicella zoster virus causes herpes zoster oticus, which can manifest with tragal tenderness. However, herpes zoster oticus is usually associated with facial paralysis and blisters in or on the ear as well as vertigo, tinnitus, and dysgeusia. Moreover, herpes zoster oticus usually results in sensorineural hearing loss rather than conductive hearing loss.

C) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus pneumoniae, a common cause of otitis media, rarely infects the external ear. While otitis media can manifest with ear pain and discharge as well as conductive hearing loss, tragal tenderness and edema of the external auditory canal are usually absent. Furthermore, otitis media tends to occur in winter months and is often associated with a history of cold and congestion.

D) INCORRECT:

Aspergillus and Candida species are the most common causal pathogens of fungal otitis externa, which can manifest with tragal pain, ear discharge, edema, and erythema. However, in fungal otitis externa, the pain is usually not severe and the edema is usually mild. Pruritus is normally the most troubling symptom. Furthermore, fungal otitis externa accounts for < 10% of all otitis externa cases and is usually associated with concurrent antibiotic use.

E) CORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most common causal pathogen of otitis externa (commonly following swimming activities). Other common causal pathogens of otitis externa include Staphylococcus epidermidis and Staphylococcus aureus.

Treatment typically involves analgesia, keeping the external acoustic meatus dry, and administering antiseptic, antibiotic, or glucocorticoid ear drops.

Key learning point: Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most common cause of otitis externa, especially after swimming, presenting with tragal tenderness, ear canal edema, and purulent discharge.
questions.hint: The patient has ear pain and purulent discharge after outdoor swimming. Examination shows an inflamed external auditory canal and conductive hearing loss. These features are consistent with otitis externa.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 5-day history of left ear pain and discharge. He works as a sound technician and uses earplugs for most of the day. Vital signs are normal. Examination of the left ear reveals a swollen pinna and malodorous discharge from the external auditory meatus; the tragus is tender to touch. Otoscopic examination shows a swollen ear canal, and the tympanic membrane is normal. Fingerstick blood glucose concentration is normal. Which one of the following initial treatments is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Otic drop containing an antibiotic and a glucocorticoid.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Clotrimazole ear drops are recommended for the treatment of fungal otitis externa, which manifests with ear pain and otorrhea. However, this condition is characterized by excessive ear itching. Antifungal therapy for AOE is indicated if the initial therapy is insufficient or if features suggestive of fungal infection (e.g., fungal filaments and spores) are seen on otoscopy.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral methylprednisolone is appropriate for acute hearing loss but not for acute otitis externa.

C) INCORRECT:

Intravenous ciprofloxacin is used in patients suspected to have malignant otitis externa (MOE). Severe ear pain and otorrhea are typical manifestations of this condition. However, this patient has no risk factors for MOE (e.g., immunosuppression, diabetes mellitus), and otoscopic examination shows no evidence of granulation tissue, which would be expected in this condition.

D) CORRECT:

Uncomplicated AOE is treated with a topical preparation that contains an antibiotic that is effective against the most common causative bacteria of AOE (e.g., aminoglycoside, fluoroquinolone), a glucocorticoid (e.g., hydrocortisone, betamethasone), and an antiseptic (e.g., alcohol, acetic acid). Further treatment includes aural toilet to remove debris and NSAIDs for pain relief. The tympanic membrane (TM) must be assessed prior to initiating therapy; if the TM is not intact or cannot be visualized, topical aminoglycosides and aural toilette are contraindicated because of an increased risk of damage to the middle ear. Ear swabs and oral antibiotic therapy should be considered if the patient does not respond to initial therapy, has severe AOE (i.e., completely occluded external auditory canal, fever, cervical lymphadenitis), or has risk factors for malignant otitis externa (e.g., immunosuppression, diabetes mellitus).

In mild cases of AOE (i.e., only mild discomfort or pruritus with minimal edema of the auditory canal), a topical preparation without an antibiotic may be considered. Patients suspected to have malignant otitis externa require a more extensive diagnostic workup (e.g., blood cultures, CT scan) and intravenous antibiotic therapy in addition to topical therapy.

Key learning point: Acute otitis externa is best treated with topical antibiotic and glucocorticoid ear drops to target common bacterial pathogens and reduce inflammation.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral amoxicillin is the first-line therapy for acute otitis media (AOM) because of its efficacy against Streptococcus pneumonia and Haemophilus influenzae, the most common causal pathogens of AOM. AOM can manifest with ear pain and otorrhea. However, AOM is also characterized by a red bulging tympanic membrane on otoscopy. Amoxicillin is not effective against Pseudomonas aeruginosa, the most common cause of acute otitis externa.
questions.hint: Severe ear pain, otorrhea, ear canal edema, and a tragus tender to touch are suggestive of acute otitis externa (AOE), which is most commonly caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Staphylococcus aureus. Using earplugs can cause injury to the skin and increase moisture in the external auditory canal, which increases the risk of AOE.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient presents with left ear pain and otorrhea for the past 3 days ago. Otoscopy shows an erythematous and edematous external auditory canal. The tympanic membrane appears intact without redness or bulging. The patient is afebrile. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral antibiotics are not indicated for uncomplicated otitis externa, as topical antimicrobials achieve much higher concentrations in the external auditory canal. Additionally, amoxicillin does not provide adequate coverage against the pathogens that typically cause otitis externa, particularly Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral antibiotics are not first-line therapy for uncomplicated otitis externa, as topical antimicrobials achieve significantly higher concentrations in the external auditory canal. Systemic antibiotics are reserved for when the infection extends beyond the canal or topical therapy is not feasible.

C) INCORRECT:

Ear canal irrigation serves as supportive therapy by removing debris and improving delivery of topical medications, but it does not treat the underlying bacterial infection.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- Topical ciprofloxacin with hydrocortisone is the most appropriate first-line treatment for otitis externa, reducing inflammation and providing antimicrobial coverage against typical pathogens, including Pseudomonas aeruginosa. As a non-ototoxic fluoroquinolone, ciprofloxacin can be used safely regardless of tympanic membrane visualization.

E) INCORRECT:

Otic hydrogen peroxide is a cerumenolytic agent used to treat cerumen impaction, but this patient's clinical presentation is more consistent with otitis externa rather than cerumen impaction.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with a 3-day history of right ear pain. On physical examination, his vital signs are normal. Otoscopy shows an erythematous tympanic membrane with decreased mobility on pneumatic otoscopy. The external auditory canal appears normal without edema or debris. He has no allergies to medications. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This adult patient presents with classic findings of acute otitis media including ear pain, erythematous tympanic membrane, and decreased mobility on pneumatic otoscopy. Amoxicillin is the first-line antibiotic for acute otitis media.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical antibiotics are generally ineffective for treating acute otitis media.

C) INCORRECT:

Hydrogen peroxide is used for cerumen removal and ear cleaning, not for treating bacterial infections of the middle ear. This agent does not provide the antimicrobial therapy needed for acute otitis media.

D) INCORRECT:

Intravenous ciprofloxacin and ceftazidime can be used to treat malignant otitis externa but are not indicated for uncomplicated acute otitis media. This patient has normal vital signs and no signs of severe systemic illness or complications that warrant parenteral therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

Clindamycin is not first-line therapy for acute otitis media. This agent is typically reserved for patients with severe penicillin allergies and/or those who have not responded to other treatments.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents to the emergency department with severe left ear pain and discharge that started 3 days ago after swimming. Physical examination shows significant erythema and edema of the external auditory canal with some purulent debris. The tympanic membrane appears normal but cannot be fully visualized due to swelling and pain. The patient has tenderness with palpation of the tragus and pinna. The patient is afebrile, and the periauricular area appears normal without cellulitis. What is the most appropriate initial antimicrobial therapy?

choices.text: Topical acetic acid with hydrocortisone drops for 7–10 days
Topical neomycin/polymyxin B/hydrocortisone drops for 7–10 days
Topical ciprofloxacin PLUS oral ciprofloxacin for 7–10 days
Topical ciprofloxacin with hydrocortisone drops for 7–10 days

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acetic acid is an antiseptic agent that is ototoxic and should only be used when the tympanic membrane is intact. Since this patient's tympanic membrane cannot be fully visualized, an alternative treatment is preferred.

B) INCORRECT:

Neomycin/polymyxin B/hydrocortisone contains aminoglycosides, which are ototoxic and should only be used when the tympanic membrane is confirmed to be intact. Since the tympanic membrane cannot be fully visualized, an alternate treatment is preferred.

C) INCORRECT:

Combination topical and oral therapy is not indicated for uncomplicated otitis externa confined to the external auditory canal. Systemic antibiotics are reserved for cases where topical therapy cannot be administered, infection extends beyond the canal, or patients with risk factors for malignant otitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral antibiotics alone are not indicated as first-line therapy for uncomplicated otitis externa. Topical antimicrobials achieve much higher concentrations in the external auditory canal tissue than systemic agents and are the preferred initial treatment when there is no evidence of infection extending beyond the canal.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – Topical ciprofloxacin with hydrocortisone is the most appropriate initial therapy for this patient with otitis externa. Since the tympanic membrane cannot be visualized due to significant canal edema, non-ototoxic agents such as fluoroquinolones should be used. Topical antimicrobials are first-line therapy and achieve superior tissue penetration compared to systemic antibiotics.
